results.title: The Twitch
results.creator_credit: Al Sens, John Taylor and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A tale of intolerance and where it all ends, told in an animated cartoon about a king and his kingdom, and bigotry that had its day. The illustrations and dialogue are light and amusing, but that does not mask the moral of the story: that unless we tolerate individual differences - even the king’s nervous twitch - peace may only come when all are behind bars. Voice and narration: Pat Burns, George Geertsen (Awards: Sydney; Melbourne)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Al Sens, John Taylor and ONF | NFB

results.title: The Twelve months examination
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Child development series”
The child’s personality has developed to the point where he has begun to relate closely to members of the family and their friends. He realises that people and objects have separate existence apart from himself, and that they continue to exist when they are out of sight. The primitive motor reflexes have been replaced with definitive motor actions.

results.title: The Twelve days of Christmas
results.brief_description: Stills from the picture book illustrated by Robert Broomfield and accompanied by the music and song. Jennifer Brown sings the lyrics as the geese, swans, doves, drummers, pipers, dancing ladies and the partridge all appear on screen.

results.title: The Turn of the tide
results.creator_credit: Ian G Wallis and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description: Discusses the ecology of the shore of Westernport Bay, Victoria, and the effects on it of waterfront settlement and development and consequent water pollution. Shows research on the problem in progress.

results.title: The Turbulent ocean
results.creator_credit: Bert Shapiro and MIT (Massachusetts Institute of Technology)
results.brief_description: A documentary film about oceanography - trying to determine theoretical eddies, to predict turbulence and ocean storms. Also an ocean-going research study to find a mode-eddy - which they did.

results.title: The Tuna coast
results.creator_credit: Fred Clarke and Tasmania. Dept. of Film Production
results.brief_description: Filmed against the splendour of the rugged south-east coast of Tasmania, the deep-sea fishing enthusiast meets his match hunting the mighty tuna. Examines the well-established sport of deep-sea fishing showing two anglers on the hunt for tuna and other big game fish.

results.title: The Trusteeship Council and system
results.creator_credit: J.C. Sheers and United Nations. Office of Public Information
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The United Nations: its charter and organization”
Demonstrates the aims, structure and mechanics of the Trusteeship Council by showing the improved standard of living and eventual independence of Somaliland under the administration of Italy.

results.title: The True story of the Civil War
results.creator_credit: Louis Clyde Stoumen and Camera Eye Pictures
results.brief_description: A record of the American Civil War period made up mostly with Mathew Brady’s original wet plate photographs made on the field of battle and contemporary newspaper illustrations (Harper’s Weekly). Relates the story of the war, describing its causes, its battles, its leaders and its effects on the nation. Narrated by Raymond Massey. (Award: Best Documentary, Short Subjects, 1957 Academy Awards)

results.title: The True story of Lili Marlene
results.creator_credit: Humphrey Jennings and Crown Film Unit
results.brief_description: A dramatic reconstruction of the British counter-propaganda campaign against the popular German forces program from the Belgrade Radio. The theme song “Lili Marlene” introduced the German “Message from Home” session. The film shows how the Germans came to use the song, how the British captured it and how the BBC turned the song to our advantage during the African Desert campaign. The British Eighth Army adopted “Lili Marlene” as their own special marching song. Appearance by Marius Goring.
